snippet: Executions could soon be reinstated in Pakistan, drawing sharp disapproval from an unlikely coalition of critics, including jihadist commanders and business leaders, albeit for entirely different reasons.
abstract: Pakistani hangman Sabir Masih has been idle in his job since 2008 when government put moratorium on capital punishment; Prime Minr Nawaz Sharif wants to reinstate death penalty but faces opposition from diverse coalition of critics including human rights activists, who report rumors that incoming Pres Mamnoon Hussain will extend moratorium.

byline.original: By DECLAN WALSH and TAHA SIDDIQUI
byline.contributor: Declan Walsh reported from London, and Taha Siddiqui from Lahore, Pakistan. Waqar Gillani contributed reporting from Lahore.

lead_paragraph: Executions could soon be reinstated in Pakistan, drawing sharp disapproval from an unlikely coalition of critics, including jihadist commanders and business leaders, albeit for entirely different reasons.

headline.main: Hangman Lacks Work, and Pakistan Looks to Provide
headline.print_headline: Hangman Lacks Work, and Pakistan Looks to Provide

keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
keywords.name: subject
